title:
Recollections of Thirty-nine Years in the Army

title: The Sea: Its Stirring Story of Adventure, Peril, & Heroism. Volume 3

quoteFirst: DESCRIPTION.--Tail shorter than the body, broad at the base, tapering gradually to a point.
quoteLast: longitudinal rows of sixteen scales on the trunk, and a mesial line of fourteen on the tail; middle nail of fore-foot much larger than the others. Scales thick, striated at base; yellowish-brown or light olive.
title: Natural History of the Mammalia of India and Ceylon
author: Sterndale, Robert Armitage, 1839-1902

quoteLast: , the ages for which school attendance laws have been relaxed and premature employment allowed.

quoteFirst: The first class, which is designed for the education of orphans and other children of the poorer class of Military Officers, and those employed in the Civil Departments of the State, consists of thirty pupils, who are received gratis, from the age of
quoteLast: years, and who remain in the Academy for years.  The second class, which is designed to assist the poorer nobility, and less opulent among the merchants, citizens, and servants of government, in giving their sons a good general education, consists of sixty pupils, who are received from the age of eleven to fifteen years, and who pay to the Academy twelve florins a month; for which sum they are fed, clothed, and instructed.
title: Essays; Political, Economical, and Philosophical — Volume 1
author: Rumford, Benjamin, Graf von, 1753-1814

quoteFirst: Shell thin walled, with smooth surface. Pores irregular, polygonal, four to eight times as broad as the bars;
quoteLast: on the radius. Six spines hexagonal pyramidal, as long as the radius, about three times as broad at the base as one pore.
title:
Report on the Radiolaria Collected by H.M.S. Challenger During the Years 1873-1876, First Part: Porulosa (Spumellaria and Acantharia)
Report on the Scientific Results of the Voyage of H.M.S. Challenger During the Years 1873-76, Vol. XVIII
author: Haeckel, Ernst, 1834-1919

quoteFirst: Cortical shell with thorny surface, and irregular, roundish pores, twice to four times as broad as the bars; seven to eight on the half meridian,
quoteLast: on the half equator of each chamber. Around both poles of the main axis occurs a circle of ten to twelve strong, radially divergent spines, about as long as the diameter of the outer medullary shell, which, like the inner, is spheroidal. (This species is identical with the younger developmental stage of _Panicium coronatum_, Pl. 40, fig.
title:
Report on the Radiolaria Collected by H.M.S. Challenger During the Years 1873-1876, First Part: Porulosa (Spumellaria and Acantharia)
Report on the Scientific Results of the Voyage of H.M.S. Challenger During the Years 1873-76, Vol. XVIII
author: Haeckel, Ernst, 1834-1919

quoteFirst: The head of the sperm whale, as seen from the side, is roughly rectangular in outline, with an exaggerated upper jaw which seems out of all manner of proportion to the lower. In large whales the height of the square forehead or nose is
quoteLast: feet, and the width of it nine to eleven feet, while the lower jaw is slender and pointed. This exaggeration of the upper part of the head does not argue anything in regard to the size of the brain, as might naturally be supposed.
title: She Blows! And Sparm at That!
author: Hopkins, William John, 1863-1926; Ashley, Clifford W. (Clifford Warren), 1881-1947 [Illustrator]
